;中美应抓住修复紧张关系的“机会之窗”观察人士表示，继美国财政部长珍妮特·耶伦相对顺利的中国之行以及气候特使约翰·克里即将访华之后，在今年晚些时候的峰会之前继续对话的希望越来越大。

;

;尽管没有取得突破与美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯上个月破冰访问首都期间相比，耶伦在为期四天的北京之行中似乎受到了更热烈的接待和媒体报道。

;

;东盟各国寻求按照自己的方式缓解美中紧张局势

;

;中国官员和官方媒体赞扬耶伦的务实主义和非对抗性做法，并普遍积极回应她关于“良性经济竞争”的呼吁中国。

;

;据观察人士称，北京发出的信息很明确：它仍然希望与华盛顿改善关系，并做好对话的准备，但美国总统乔·拜登的政府是否应该主动将双边关系置于首位？中美关系重回正轨。

;

;中国财政部在周一的一份声明中高度评价耶伦的访问以及她与多位中国官员进行的“坦诚、务实、深入和建设性”的会晤。呼吁拜登政府对华采取“理性务实”态度，“以实际行动回应中方对美国经济制裁和打压的重大关切”。

;

;美国问题专家吕翔中国社科院事务部表示，随着高层交往的恢复，两国迎来了稳定关系的“机会之窗”。

;

;“虽然没有取得实质性成果，但耶伦此行会议取得了成功，因为气氛明显改善，避免了‘比最坏更糟糕’的情况，”他说。 “尽管双边关系还远未见底，但双方至少都表达了继续前进、改善关系的愿望。”

;

;周日，在离开北京前不久，接受美国公共媒体市场节目采访时耶伦表示，尽管存在“重大分歧”，她此行还是实现了为双边关系奠定基础的目标。

;

;“挑战存在，但我相信双方都有稳定关系的愿望并建设性地解决我们每个人在我们的关系中看到的问题，坦诚地、坦诚地、尊重地这样做，并建立一种富有成效的关系，”她说。

;

;“这是”

;

;在访问期间，美联储前主席耶伦周五会见了中国第二号领导人李强。周六与美中贸易和经济领域的中国领导人何立峰进行了五个小时的会议。

;

;李克强总理着眼于经济关键时刻的“组合拳”

;

;她还会见了几位现任和退休的中国官员，包括财政部长刘昆、央行行长易纲，以及被广泛视为易纲继任者的潘功胜、中国前经济部长刘鹤和易纲的前任周小川。

;

;周日早些时候，耶伦将这次会晤描述为“直接、实质性和富有成效”，并表示它们使美中关系更接近“更稳固的基础”。

;

;耶伦表示，她明确表示华盛顿并不像北京担心的那样与中国经济脱钩，因为这样做将“对两国造成灾难，并破坏世界稳定”。

;

;她还试图缓解北京日益增长的焦虑关于美国对先进技术的出口管制和其他针对中国的行动，称其动机是“直接的国家安全考虑”和供应链多元化，而不是“获得经济优势”。

;

;“我想缓解他们担心我们会做一些会对中国经济产生广泛影响的事情。”耶伦说。

;

;不过，北京显然仍然持怀疑态度，中国官员对美国的制裁和其他限制性措施表示不满，据官方通讯社新华社报道，何副总理警告美国，“笼统国家安全”不利于经济交流。

;

;与布林肯上个月首次访问北京时受到的冷淡欢迎相比，卢表示，作为美国最高外交官，北京显然将耶伦视为拜登政府中更友好的人物。

;

;“从北京的角度来看，耶伦确实与布林肯和其他负责安全和外交政策的人不同”他说。

;

;“虽然她不可能放弃拜登政府对中国的敌对策略，但耶伦的整体态度更加温和务实，她不像布林肯那样教条。这就是气氛好得多的原因。”

;

;华盛顿史汀生中心中国项目主任孙云表示，耶伦的访问是有助于修复关系的另一个积极因素。

;

;“积极因素很多，对于稳定两国关系绝对有好处。但如果负面因素仍然存在，就不太可能重置或重新定义双边关系。”她补充说，耶伦和布林肯的中国之行可能有助于为期待已久的会晤奠定基础中国国家主席习近平和拜登于 11 月在旧金山举行的亚太经合组织 (APEC) 峰会上进行了会谈。

;

;“情况一定会好转，紧张局势肯定会在亚太经合组织峰会，届时两位领导人预计将于 11 月会面。”她说。

;

;但考虑到在台湾、新疆和其他问题上不断升温的敌对行动和对抗，这种解冻能持续多久仍不清楚。南海对美国的出口禁令和俄罗斯入侵乌克兰。

;

;“没有人知道亚太经合组织峰会后会发生什么，因为美国即将进入明年总统选举的选举周期，”孙说

;

;耶伦还会见了在华美国企业代表，提出中国针对美国企业的“非市场”做法和“强制行动”，警告中国企业不要为俄罗斯乌克兰战争提供物质支持。

;

;据美国财政部称，她周六还邀请了一群中国女性经济学家和企业家共进午餐，以“与正常政策结构之外的一些人进行互动”。< /p>;

;76 岁的耶伦是第一位担任美联储主席的女性，她试图强调女性对经济的贡献以及她们面临的挑战，她说：“当我几乎是美联储中唯一的女性时，我一直看到这一点。”房间”或决策桌上。

;

;但她的关键信息似乎是针对中国人民的。 “让我明确一点：虽然美国与中国政府存在分歧，但这并不是与中国人民的分歧。”

;

;然而，她强调性别多样性的努力招致了中国极端民族主义者在社交媒体上的攻击，她称耶伦午餐会上的女性为“激进女权主义者”、叛徒和美国间谍。

;

;耶伦在美国也因在会见贺建奎和其他中国官员时多次鞠躬而受到批评，一些媒体和观察人士称这是拜登政府软弱的表现。

;

;卢表示，针对耶伦和华人妇女群体的批评既不公平，又没有根据。但他表示，耶伦在整个行程中显得很紧张，在大多数场合都坚持她准备好的剧本，包括在全女性午餐会上。

;

;四川大学国际事务教授庞中英表示，民族主义的强烈反对反对耶伦访华突显了两国之间日益加深的分歧以及两国公众观念的强化。

;

;他指出，与布林肯不同，耶伦没有会见当时不在城里的习近平 — —有迹象表明，双边关系仍处于低位。

;

;“耶伦在美国很受尊敬，她知道如何轻声说话，但她的礼貌不应被误认为是软弱的表现， ”他说。

;

;庞将布林肯和耶伦的访问以及美国气候特使约翰·克里本周末的访问描述为美国的和解姿态。

;

;“确实，这是一个机会之窗，但可能是短暂的。现在美国又伸出了橄榄枝，表示愿意接触，同时防止美中竞争失控。所有的目光都将集中在中国，中国是否愿意并能够抓住这个机会还有待观察。

;

;但庞观察到，总体而言，情绪仍然悲观，北京方面对美国持反对态度在中国经济和社会持续低迷的情况下，中国主导了全球化。

;

;陆还警告说，随着对习拜登在亚太经合组织峰会上会面的期望上升，不要寄希望于双边关系会大幅改善。

;

; “现在需要在接下来的几个月（11 月峰会之前）取得突破，”他说。 “中美在经贸问题上取得的突破无论多么小，对两国和全球经济来说都是好消息。但如果不能取得进展，北京可能会认为这些交流是浪费时间，是美国试图将其对华遏制政策合法化。”

;

;鲁还指出，耶伦的到来恰逢习近平的视察。中国人民解放军东部战区司令部驻江苏，负责管辖台湾海峡和苏州工业园区。习近平呼吁加强战争准备和战斗准备，加大力度增强自给自足和国产技术，以应对美国领导的对华科技战。

;

;“两次视察都是为了自力更生和自主创新，这表明中国虽然希望看到美国和中国有一个友好的环境，但仍然为“最坏情况和极端情况”可能出现的危险风暴做好准备，”他说。

;苹果正在微信上推出官方虚拟店面，扩大其在中国的销售网络，作为该国最受欢迎的消息应用程序，这家美国科技巨头正在慢慢将生产转移到亚洲其他地方，作为减少对中国工厂依赖的努力的一部分。

;

;这家加州公司的 Apple Store 迷你应用程序在根据周二的一份声明，微信与其官方网站在线商店一起提供一系列服务。该小应用程序允许微信用户按产品类别浏览和搜索，查看产品详细信息和相关培训课程，以及下订单和跟踪订单。

;

;但是，新商店不提供大幅折扣或高额补贴。主要促销活动为想要用旧 iPhone 机型换取最新 iPhone 14 或 iPhone 14 Pro 的用户提供高达 5,500 元人民币（306 美元）的积分。

;

;Apple 已在中国开设了店面。主要电子商务平台，包括京东、拼多多和天猫（由《南华早报》所有者阿里巴巴集团控股公司运营的市场）。

;

;微信商店为苹果提供了另一个直接销售的渠道根据大学咨询的报告，中国是全球最大的消费电子市场，预计到 2023 年将达到 2283 亿美元，而美国为 1550 亿美元，印度为 691.5 亿美元。

;

;尽管如此尽管担心苹果的供应链可能过度集中在中国，但中国仍然是该公司继美洲和欧洲之后的最大海外市场。

;

;去年 10 月在中国销售的每四部智能手机中，就有一部是 iPhone，其中根据市场研究公司 Counterpoint 的数据，9 月份发布的 iPhone 14 Pro Max 和 14 Pro 是最畅销的两款手机。

;

;尽管如此，随着中国经济增长放缓 - 苹果在中国大陆、香港、澳门的销量3 月份季度，台湾地区同比下降 2.9%，而全球地区同比下降 2.5%，而且随着中国人口数量超过印度，苹果公司越来越多地转向印度消费者寻求增长。

;

;今年到目前为止，这家 iPhone 制造商已在这个南亚国家开设了两家专卖店，希望能够迎合当地消费者从廉价设备转向中端和高端设备的偏好。

;香港事实上的中央银行香港金融管理局 (HKMA) 宣布“有序退出”小企业贷款还款假期，该假期将于 7 月底到期。

;

;该计划于 2020 年 5 月开始，是一项为期六个月的措施，旨在帮助企业生存冠状病毒大流行导致的业务衰退，使数千家符合条件的公司推迟支付企业贷款和抵押贷款的本金。该期限已延长六次。

;

;金管局在周二晚间的一份声明中表示，“该计划的重点将从帮助企业应对疫情转移到促进企业恢复正常还款”。

;

;据金管局称，该计划包括约 100 家银行参与，覆盖约 120,000 家年销售额低于 8 亿港元（1.03 亿美元）且无严重逾期贷款的合资格企业借款人。

;

; 据金管局称，从 11 月到 1 月，该计划的参与率下降至 1%，即 1,300 家符合资格的公司，而三年前首次推出时，参与率为 16%，即 19,000 家参与企业。

;

;同时，选择部分偿还本金的企业数量稳步增加，表明部分企业的还款能力有所改善。

;

;随着部分企业现金流状况的改善，声明称，由于尚未完全恢复，金管局还制定了安排“增强现有的部分本金偿还选择，以促进逐步过渡到正常还款”。

;

;香港是全球金融的一部分金管局首席执行官：对于包括抵押贷款和商用车贷款在内的分期贷款，企业可以选择在 12 至 18 个月的延长期限内偿还 20% 的本金，也可以选择在 12 至 18 个月的期限内偿还 50% 的本金声明称，对于贸易便利，银行应与客户讨论其情况，并允许他们在24个月内定期分期还款。

;

;金管局表示，银行需要联系参与该计划的公司，了解其是否选择部分本金偿还安排。

;

;香港从 3 级增至 2 级首次关注主要银行系统变化

;

;公司将在 10 月底之前通知其银行。否则，他们将需要恢复正常付款。

;

;金管局还呼吁银行“继续同情那些未参与该计划但因现金流压力而面临现金流压力的企业的资金需求”

;

;金管局已推出多轮针对中小型企业的纾缓措施。

;

;截至6月底，银行已批准超过118,000份申请延长贷款期限及其他形式的纾困，涉及金额1.2万亿港元。

;北京主管香港事务的最高领导机构升级后召开首次会议河南省委副书记兼省安全厅厅长、59 岁的周济证实了《华盛顿邮报》的独家报道，港澳事务办公室表示，港澳事务办公室以常务副主任身份出席了周二的会议。

;

;会议还透露了改组后的办公室领导班子阵容，夏宝龙继续担任主任，由五名助理人员协助

;

;港澳办发布的一张照片显示，夏正主持会议，周和中央政府驻香港联络办公室主任郑彦雄坐在他的两侧。

;

;驻澳门中联办主任郑新聪、资深外交官杨万明和中国内地顶尖社会科学家王令贵担任副主任。

;

;国务院确认了三位新副主任的任命——周恩来、郑彦雄和郑新聪——在周二下午的另一份声明中。在之前的版本中，副主任的角色被描述为香港和澳门两个联络办公室负责人的“兼任”。

;

;港澳办表示，石克辉将继续担任该办公室的纪律检查和监察组组长。 ”经过三个多月的密集重组，该办公室领导层被改组为一个更高级别的机构，直接向党而不是国务院报告。

;

;此次改组实际上提升了该办公室在中国权力等级制度中的地位因为现在大多数决策权掌握在以习近平主席为核心的党机关手中。

;

;周恩来被任命为二号人物——负责日常运作的官员– 距离他的前任张晓明被任命为中国最高政治咨询机构中国人民政治协商会议 (CPPCC) 副秘书长近一年。

;

;《华盛顿邮报》报道称，夏取代了周 –之前没有在香港或澳门工作的经验 – 前往深圳和珠海进行就职旅行。周有望接替夏，后者的任期已超过国家官员通常的退休年龄。

;

;北京的香港问题关键人物试图缓解对香港声誉的担忧

;

;刘兆教授-北京半官方智库中国港澳研究会顾问凯表示，没有涉港工作经验，不会影响周对香港事务的监督。

;

;“该办公室是刘说：“香港和澳门是直接受共产党中央领导的，这意味着任命的官员应该赢得北京的高度信任，并具备以国家和国际视野处理香港和澳门事务的能力。”

;< p>;相反，刘看到了周恩来的任命的优点，因为他可以超越当地特定部门的既得利益。

;

;他表示，有了新的港澳办领导班子，北京将有信心完成分配的工作”

;

;“他之前的经验和人脉可能有助于香港更好地融入大湾区，特别是在科技和新工业化领域，而香港正是在这些领域。” “现在正着眼于发展成为新的经济引擎。”刘说。

;

;湾区是指北京将香港、澳门和中国内地九个城市整合为经济强国的计划。

;

;中国驻印度高级特使一职自10月以来一直空缺，前任大使孙卫东在新德里任职三年后返回北京，担任外交部副部长。

;

;这是四十年来最长的一次差距，反映出中国与中国本已紧张的关系有可能进一步恶化。

;

;由于这两个亚洲大国没有表现出结束危险的军事对峙的意愿，这场对峙始于 2020 年 6 月拉达克东部发生的致命边境冲突，因此新德里果断地倾向于华盛顿。

;

;印度加强了与美国的军事关系，以制衡中国，在加入“四方”方面迈出了重要一步。“四方”是一个由美国领导、与日本和澳大利亚组成的四方组织，北京方面将其斥为“四方”组织。 “印度-太平洋北约”。

;

;这种提升在上个月纳伦德拉·莫迪总理历史性访问白宫期间得到体现，华盛顿消除了广泛的国防、高科技和出口贸易壁垒，寻求将两国关系提升为平等的全球战略伙伴关系。

;

;然后上周，美国总统乔·拜登负责印太地区的高级官员库尔特·坎贝尔 (Kurt Campbell) 将印度描述为“最受欢迎的国家之一” ”并称赞美印关系是“地球上最重要的双边关系”。

;

;几十年来，美国总统和高级官员一直将华盛顿与北京的关系称为最重要的关系以及随之而来的世界双边关系。

;

;坎贝尔的言论标志着美国外交政策优先事项的里程碑式转变，美国外交政策优先事项已从 1970 年代初以来的接触急剧转变为遏制中国崛起的冷战式遏制战略

;

;三周前，拜登在白宫与莫迪一起讲话，他亲眼目睹了过去五年接触战略的兴衰，他明确表示，他的外交政策是价值观驱动的。

;

;“我认为美中关系不像美印关系那样，根本原因之一是我们彼此之间存在压倒性的尊重，因为我们都是民主国家， ” the US leader said.

;

;But that does not mean Washington and New Delhi see eye to eye on many critical issues, such as India's human rights abuses, its refusal to condemn Russia's aggression against Ukraine, and Washington's security ties with Delhi's arch-rival Islamabad.

;

;Aside from the China factor, what matters most in Delhi's strategic pivot towards Washington seems to be the US assurance that it will not lecture India over its ties with Russia.;

;“We are investing in a relationship that we are not going to judge by one issue, even if that issue is quite consequential, but rather that we are going to judge over the fullness of time, as we try to work on convergence on the major strategic questions facing our two countries,” US national security adviser Jake Sullivan said in June last year.

;

;“On one of those questions, how to deal with the challenge posed by China, there is much more convergence today and that is important to US foreign policy.”

;

;With that in mind, Washington has pledged to support Delhi in its border dispute with Beijing regardless, which will no doubt constrain China's options in seeking a way out of the tense border situation.

;

;Biden defends his calling Xi a dictator as Modi feted with state visit

;

;Modi's latest snub of Chinese President Xi Jinping's signature Belt and Road Initiative at the virtual Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit early this month has increased uncertainty over the prospect of bilateral ties and in particular Xi's much-speculated plan to attend the G20 summit in the Indian capital in September.

;

;The absence of a Chinese ambassador in Delhi has made it even more difficult for both sides to manage their differences.

;

;With Delhi set to displace Beijing in Washington's hierarchy of external relations and the US offering support to help India's rise – support that may be comparable to that provided by Washington to Beijing over the years – India's time may have finally come, as Modi and other analysts have repeatedly proclaimed.

;

;Delhi may not want to be part of “any kind of 'containment' of China”, according to former Indian foreign secretary Shyam Saran, but there is no denying about the intensifying rivalry between China and India.

;

;Both countries aspire to become a regional and even global superpower, and Delhi is set to rise to become a foremost geopolitical rival for Beijing in the many years and decades to come. Could this be a Thucydides Trap between China and India in the making?

; Tue, 11 Jul 2023 21:20:08 +0800 Could Chinese team’s new EV battery tech offer top-class performance at a fraction of the cost?https://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3227344/could-chinese-teams-new-ev-battery-tech-offer-top-class-performance-fraction-cost?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.11 21:10;
;;

;Chinese scientists say they have developed a new solid-state battery technology to match cutting-edge performance at just 4 per cent of the cost.

;

;Most EV batteries are of the lithium-iron phosphate or ternary lithium variety, and each has its own merits in terms of cost stability and energy density. However, both contain liquid electrolytes.

;

;Liquids have a lower energy storage density than solids. Despite advancements in liquid battery technology, their bulkiness, weight and potential fire risk prevent their usage in lightweight EVs.

;

;But researchers at the University of Science and Technology of China (USTC) in Anhui province have been able to develop all-solid-state batteries – using solid electrolytes for conduction – that also come at a fraction of the cost, holding out great promise for commercial applications of the technology.

;

;Solid-state batteries have numerous advantages over the conventional kind, such as double the energy density, faster charging speeds, and unrestricted charging temperatures.

;

;As they are non-flammable, non-corrosive and leakproof, these next-generation batteries also represent a much safer option for the electric vehicle and energy storage industries.

;

;However, large-scale application has been held back by high production costs.

;

;Solid electrolytes require expensive metals like lanthanum and cobalt, and the manufacturing process calls for a high degree of precision and dedicated production lines.

;

;China ranks 3rd for readiness to boost output of metals for clean energy drive

;

;To address this challenge, a USTC team led by Professor Ma Cheng developed a new solid electrolyte, called lithium zirconium oxychloride. Its performance was found to be comparable to that of advanced sulphide and chloride solid electrolytes but at only 4 per cent of the cost, according to findings published in peer-reviewed journal Nature Communications last month.

;

;A commercially viable solid-state lithium battery electrolyte must show high ionic conductivity, good “deformability” or capacity for shock absorption, and cost under US$50 per kg.

;

;None of the existing electrolytes can meet all these criteria. Ceramic electrolytes generally lack deformability, while sulphides and chlorides are expensive, all costing over US$200 per kg.

;

;However, the lithium zirconium oxychloride electrolyte developed by Ma and his team achieved room-temperature ionic conductivity that was more than double the standard required for real-life application. Meanwhile, its excellent deformability allowed the material to maintain its shape under high pressure, meeting application requirements.

;

;“The team provided two synthesis routes, one with a raw material cost of only US$11.6 per kg and the other less than US$7 per kg. In application tests, a battery using lithium zirconium oxychloride took only 12 minutes to charge and maintained stable cycles over 2,000 times at room temperature,” USTC said in a statement.

;

;Both the academic community and industrial producers have speeded up their pursuit of this next generation technology. However, China's EV companies have so far opted for semi-solid batteries, given the high material and manufacturing costs of the all-solid variety.

;

;Japanese car giant Toyota, which uses sulphides as solid electrolytes, is also planning to commercialise solid-state battery technology, The Financial Times reported on July 4.

;

;Keiji Kaita, president of Toyota's Carbon Neutral Advanced Engineering Development Centre, said their goal was to halve the size, weight and cost of both liquid and solid batteries, according to the report.

;

;He said Toyota had developed methods to improve battery durability and believed it could manufacture solid-state batteries with a range of 1,200km (745 miles) and a charging time of 10 minutes or less.

;

;Toyota's push will undoubtedly intensify competition in the EV battery field with China, whose lithium-ion battery exports last year accounted for nearly 70 per cent of global shipments.

;

;However, Toyota's products are not expected to hit the market until at least 2025, with mass production likely only after 2027.

;

;“With the world's largest new energy vehicle market and a leading position in relevant scientific publications, China is poised to make significant strides in the industrialisation of solid-state batteries,” Dong Yang, vice-chairman of the China Electric Vehicle Association think tank told Shanghai-based website Guancha in January.

; Tue, 11 Jul 2023 21:20:08 +0800 Australian lawmakers grill TikTok, Meta officials over China links, foreign interference, Covid-19 originshttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3227347/australian-lawmakers-grill-tiktok-meta-officials-over-china-links-foreign-interference-covid-19?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.11 21:10;
;;

;Australian representatives of TikTok and Meta on Tuesday faced a grilling from lawmakers in Canberra over the platforms' efforts to combat foreign interference, in scenes reminiscent of the congressional pile-on faced by TikTok's chief executive in the United States in March.

;

;The inquiry, aimed at studying ways in which Australia's democracy was harmed by foreign interference through social media, took a combative turn with the prominent China hawk, Senator James Paterson, presiding over the hearing.

;

;Paterson sought to make the hearing specifically about China, as he questioned the TikTok representatives about China's alleged rights abuses in Xinjiang and alluded to the conspiracy theory that Covid-19 originated from Wuhan – asking if content relating to the theory was categorised as misinformation by the platforms.

;

;Australia bans TikTok on government devices

;

;TikTok's Australian director of public policy Ella Woods-Joyce said the company did not “censor or promote content based on any political sensitivity”, but Paterson asked her why only “5.6 per cent” of TikTok content on Xinjiang in August 2020 was critical of the Communist Party, citing research from the Australian Strategic Policy Institute think tank.

;

;“So it's just a coincidence, that 95 per cent of the content about Xinjiang on TikTok is positive, when bodies like Human Rights Watch, and Amnesty International, and the United Nations and many governments around the world, said there's either crimes against humanity, genocide, or other serious human rights abuses happening? Does that sound natural to you?” he said.

;

;“Let me ask you your opinion, do you think there are human rights abuses occurring in Xinjiang?”

;

;Similar to questions faced by TikTok's chief executive Shou Zi Chew in March, Paterson also asked Woods-Joyce if TikTok's parent company, ByteDance, was a Chinese company and whether it had an “internal Communist Party committee”.

;

;“Your reluctance to acknowledge basic facts about the parent company with whom you're ultimately employed is not a promising start to your willingness to honestly answer these questions … because it is a clearly established fact that there's a [Communist Party] committee in ByteDance,” he said.

;

;Beijing-based ByteDance has repeatedly insisted that it is not owned by the Chinese state, with some 60 per cent of its shares owned by non-Chinese investors, including Western social media platforms LinkedIn and Twitter.

;

;Paterson applied the same combative tone of questioning with TikTok's US data security expert Will Farrell, and Australian general manager Lee Hunter, either cutting them off or criticising them for being evasive.

;

;Representatives of Meta – owner of Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and Threads – as well as LinkedIn were also quizzed about China in Tuesday's hearings. In particular, they were asked about “wrongly labelling” content about the so-called lab leak theory as misinformation.

;

;“Now I should stress we don't know still, today, whether it was natural in origin, or whether it came from the Wuhan Institute of Neurology,” Paterson said. “Either way, that seems like an issue which should be up for debate until we do have conclusive answers on that either way, but it was restricted on your platform. Do you have any reflections or lessons learned from that?”

;

;Meta's Director of Policy for Australia and New Zealand Mia Garlick said the company worked with the best advice it received during what were “extraordinary circumstances”.

;

;Australians see benefits of strong China ties but want Chinese apps banned: poll

;

;The origins of Covid-19 have been furiously debated in the international community, with some in the US and countries such as Australia insisting that the virus has its origins in a laboratory in Wuhan, where the first human cases were reported in 2019.

;

;China has said there is no credibility to this theory, and US intelligence agencies in June said they found no direct evidence to support it – even though they could not rule out the possibility that the virus came from a laboratory.

;

;There had been expectations before the hearing that it would serve as an opportunity for lawmakers to grill representatives from Tencent-owned WeChat, the Chinese superapp. Apart from its ubiquity at home, the app is very popular with the global Chinese diaspora.

;

;WeChat has no permanent representatives in Australia, and hence Canberra lawmakers were unable to mandate executives to be present at the hearing. Tencent said on Monday that despite its absence, it took legal compliance in all its markets seriously and looked forward to engaging with Australian stakeholders.

;

;Paterson had earlier warned in a letter to the company that its absence would lead his committee to “inevitably draw conclusions about its willingness to cooperate with Australian law”.

;

;

;

;Of the 40 submissions received by the committee, some called for an outright ban on China-linked WeChat and TikTok.

;

;A fresh submission by two Australian experts on WeChat published over the weekend ahead of the hearings, however, said banning these apps would damage Australia's democracy.

;

;During the last set of hearings in April, the inquiry heard from witnesses who said the Chinese government had used WeChat to harass them and their families.

;

;That set of testimony was fiercely debated, with proponents of the ban describing WeChat as a “narrative machine for the [Communist Party]” while others suggested a ban was hypocritical and giving Western-owned platforms a free pass even though some were part-owned by entities linked to states with questionable rights records.

;

;WeChat to skip Australian social media hearing on 'political interference'

;

;The fresh submissions by leading Australian WeChat researchers Wanning Sun of the University of Technology Sydney, and RMIT's Haiqing Yu, argued that a ban on WeChat would inadvertently hurt Australian democracy.

;

;They noted that some 1.2 million Australians of mainland Chinese heritage used WeChat. A ban is “potentially damaging to social cohesion, and is likely to be seen as racially and politically motivated”, they said.

;

;They also made the distinction that WeChat and its Chinese version, Weixin, were separate systems, with WeChat being operated by an entity based in Singapore.

;

;Yu said Paterson's persistent invitation for WeChat to attend the inquiry would have set up a “trap” for the social media platform. “The purpose is to use WeChat as the pawn in [the] long game of continuing the China threat narrative, to create media panic about Chinese platforms and Chinese influence,” she said.

;

;The hearing will continue on Wednesday, with representatives of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and cybersecurity section of the Australian Federal Police expected to testify.

;The Hong Kong Heritage Museum will mark the 50th anniversary of kung fu legend Bruce Lee's death this month with a pop-up exhibition featuring items from popular culture related to the star and stage a day camp for primary school pupils.

;

;The five-day camp will form part of the “Bruce Lee: a Timeless Classic” exhibition at the Sha Tin museum, which opens on Wednesday and pays tribute to the star who died on July 20, 1973 at the age of 32.

;

;Museum director Brian Lam Kwok-fai said Camp Bruce Lee, which runs from next Tuesday, was a great opportunity for young children to find out more about the legend's life and philosophy, and to build lifelong friendships with other participants.

;

;“Camp Bruce Lee usually takes place in different cities in the United States. We have been collaborating with the Bruce Lee Foundation and making the camp happen in Hong Kong for the first time,” Lam said on Tuesday.

;

;“The foundation helped us to modify the programme to suit Hong Kong and provided us with Chinese course materials.”

;

;Revamped Bruce Lee exhibition to open in Hong Kong, with 200 unseen items

;

;The camp will feature workshops on the star's legacy, drama, and mindfulness in Chinese tea culture, exploring Lee's philosophy of “be water, my friend” through sensory experience with sand arts.

;

;It also includes an introduction to jeet kune do, a martial arts philosophy Lee developed, including basic postures, punches and kicks, while participants will meet the star's daughter Shannon Lee online to share what they have learned on the last day.

;

;Lam said the museum had received about 100 applications in June and shortlisted 30 Primary Four to Six students to take part.

;

;“We set a small quota because it will be the first time Hong Kong hosts the camp. We will conclude it and share our experience with the foundation and intend to host more through collaboration in the future,” Lam added.

;

;The director said the biggest challenge over the pop-up display was not to duplicate “A Man Beyond the Ordinary: Bruce Lee”, a showcase of 400 exhibits already in another museum gallery.

;

;King Hu, Chang Cheh, Bruce Lee, Jackie Chan: a martial arts cinema history

;

;The pop-up display, which runs until January 1 next year, focuses on popular culture inspired by Lee from films, comics, animation to action figures, including a life-size bust of the star holding nunchucks.

;

;The 1950 film The Kid, in which Lee played a delinquent orphan, will be screened at 2pm on July 22 at the museum and a talk held afterwards from around 3.30pm to 5pm on a first come, first served basis for 300 people.

;

;Lee paired up with seasoned actor Yee Chau-shui in The Kid, creating an interesting contrast between youth and experience in the film and showing that kindness could exist in a harsh and dangerous world.

;

;Bruce Lee at 80: the martial arts legend and his legacy

;

;Veteran actress Alice Fung So-bor and film critic Sam Ho Sze-wing will host an in-depth discussion on the movie's casting, plot and historical background and share their stories and views on 1950s filmmaking techniques, Lee's early acting career and the social and cultural context of post-war Hong Kong.

;

;All events in the programme are free of charge.

;;

;China is embracing a domestic travel boom as the summer holiday season began with crowded airports, adding a “lipstick effect” against a gloomy economic recovery backdrop in recent months.

;

;Domestic passenger traffic has exceeded pre-coronavirus levels, data from multiple flight-tracking platforms suggested, with parents and children enjoying the first summer without stringent coronavirus restrictions since 2020.

;

;But the recovery of international travel remains sluggish, with the 7,100 flights operated in the week that ended on Sunday representing just 46 per cent of pre-pandemic level, according to flight tracking app Hangban Guanjia.

;

;Around 103,000 flights took place in China during the same seven-day period, up by 7 per cent from the same period in 2019, according to figures from VariFlight, a civil aviation data services provider.

;

;Almost 9 million people flew via Chinese airports in the first five days of July, up by around 14 per cent from the pre-coronavirus period, according to FlightAI, a market insight platform affiliated with online travelling agency Trip.com.

;

;“There is a lipstick effect in tourism. When the economy is bleak, people won't spend on real estate, but they're willing to make small expenditures such as travelling or outdoor activities,” said He Jianmin, a professor of tourism at the Shanghai University of Finance and Economics.

;

;He was referring to the so-called lipstick index, a theory which suggests consumers are more willing to buy less costly luxury goods during an economic crisis.

;

;China's economic figures in recent months have fuelled concern over its post-coronavirus recovery, with challenges ranging from limited domestic and foreign investment to a drop in exports and an ailing property market.

;

;However, high growth in tourism is expected to continue as the sector gradually recovers from three years of virus control measures, He added.

;

;Domestic travel had seen an annual growth rate of between 8 to 10 per cent before 2019, when around 6 billion trips were recorded, according to government data.

;

;China is also a huge market for global aviation, accounting for 9 per cent of all international air passenger demand before the pandemic, according to the International Air Transport Association.

;

;But uncertainties, including the war in Ukraine and the global economic downturn, have hindered Chinese tourists' return to overseas travel, said He.

;

;“Domestic travel agencies need more time to reconnect with overseas partners, many of whom may have gone bankrupt during the past years. So the entire industry needs to be restructured,” he said.

;

;Major Chinese airlines have accelerated their resumption of international routes since late last month ahead of the summer holiday, bringing back a series of flights for European destinations, including Rome and Frankfurt.

;

;But they are still far from the levels in 2019, which will not be reached until the end of next year, according to a previous estimate from the China Air Transport Association.
